message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The microbiome extends host evolutionary potential
Paper Abstract: Abstract The microbiome shapes many host traits, yet the biology of microbiomes challenges traditional evolutionary models. Here, we illustrate how integrating the microbiome into quantitative genetics can help untangle complexities of host-microbiome evolution. We describe two general ways in which the microbiome may affect host evolutionary potential: by shifting the mean host phenotype and by changing the variance in host phenotype in the population. We synthesize the literature across diverse taxa and discuss how these scenarios could shape the host response to selection. We conclude by outlining key avenues of research to improve our understanding of the complex interplay between hosts and microbiomes.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Natural selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_selection"},{"title":"Natural Selection (2011 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_Selection_(2011_film)"},{"title":"Natural Selection (Fuel album) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_Selection_(Fuel_album)"},{"title":"Cosmological natural selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmological_natural_selection"},{"title":"On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties; and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/On_the_Tendency_of_Species_to_form_Varieties;_and_on_the_Perpetuation_of_Varieties_and_Species_by_Natural_Means_of_Selection"},{"title":"The Genetical Theory of Natural Selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Genetical_Theory_of_Natural_Selection"},{"title":"Natural Selection (Art Department album) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_Selection_(Art_Department_album)"},{"title":"No Struggle for Existence, No Natural Selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_Struggle_for_Existence,_No_Natural_Selection"},{"title":"Talk:Natural selection/Archive 2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Natural_selection/Archive_002"},{"title":"On the Origin of Species - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/On_the_Origin_of_Species"}]

I've performed a web search for "natural selection." Here are the key results:

## Definition and Core Concept

Natural selection is the differential survival and reproduction of individuals due to differences in the relative fitness endowed on them by their own particular complement of observable characteristics.(no content)Individuals best adapted to their environments are more likely to survive and reproduce.

## How Natural Selection Works

Variation of traits, both genotypic and phenotypic, exists within all populations of organisms. However, some traits are more likely to facilitate survival and reproductive success. Thus, these traits are more likely to be passed on to the next generation.

## Historical Development

The concept, published by Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace in a joint presentation of papers in 1858, was elaborated in Darwin's influential 1859 book On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life.

## Significance in Biology

Natural selection is a cornerstone of modern biology.(no content)With the development of the modern evolutionary synthesis in the 1930s and 1940s, Darwin's concept of evolutionary adaptation through natural selection became central to modern evolutionary theory, and it has now become the unifying concept of the life sciences.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "evolutionary biology"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Ecology and evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology_and_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"Portal:Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Journal of Evolutionary Biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"European Society for Evolutionary Biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Society_for_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary biology journals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_biology_journals"},{"title":"Glossary of genetics and evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_genetics_and_evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Planck_Institute_for_Evolutionary_Biology"},{"title":"Index of evolutionary biology articles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Index_of_evolutionary_biology_articles"}]

Here are the key results from the web search on **evolutionary biology**:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Evolutionary biology is a subfield of biology that analyzes the four mechanisms of evolution: natural selection, mutation, genetic drift, and gene flow.(no content)The purpose of evolutionary biology is to observe the diversity of life on Earth.

## Scope and Study Areas

Evolutionary biology explains diversity between species by analyzing changes in a few individuals within a population over multiple generations, with the purpose of determining how genetic variation develops, how it is inherited, and how the evolutionary mechanisms shape a population's genetic composition.(no content)Research processes are studied at different levels of complexity from observing features in living or fossilized species to analyzing DNA genomic sequencing between species.

## Historical Development

The idea of evolution by natural selection was proposed by Charles Darwin in 1859, but evolutionary biology as an academic discipline in its own right emerged during the period of the modern synthesis in the 1930s and 1940s, with many universities not having departments of evolutionary biology until the 1980s.

## Modern Research Approaches

The newer field of evolutionary developmental biology ("evo-devo") investigates how embryogenesis is controlled, thus yielding a wider synthesis that integrates developmental biology with the fields of study covered by the earlier evolutionary synthesis.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "quantitative genetics"

Links: [{"title":"Quantitative genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantitative_genetics"},{"title":"Template:Quantitative genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Quantitative_genetics"},{"title":"Quantitative trait locus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantitative_trait_locus"},{"title":"Talk:Quantitative genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quantitative_genetics"},{"title":"Complex traits - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_traits"},{"title":"Infinitesimal model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinitesimal_model"},{"title":"Douglas Scott Falconer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_Scott_Falconer"},{"title":"Christine F. Baes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christine_F._Baes"},{"title":"Richard Frankham - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Frankham"},{"title":"Protein quantitative trait loci - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protein_Quantitative_Trait_Loci"}]

I've found comprehensive information about quantitative genetics. Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition and Overview

Quantitative genetics is the study of quantitative traits, which are phenotypes that vary continuously—such as height or mass—as opposed to phenotypes and gene-products that are discretely identifiable—such as eye-colour, or the presence of a particular biochemical.

## Key Concepts

Polygenic inheritance refers to inheritance of a phenotypic characteristic (trait) that is attributable to two or more genes and can be measured quantitatively, while multifactorial inheritance refers to polygenic inheritance that also includes interactions with the environment.(no content)Multifactorial traits outside of illness result in what we see as continuous characteristics in organisms, especially human organisms such as: height, skin color, and body mass.

## Quantitative Trait Loci (QTLs)

A quantitative trait locus (QTL) is a locus (section of DNA) that correlates with variation of a quantitative trait in the phenotype of a population of organisms.(no content)Analysis of quantitative trait loci, or QTLs, is a more recent addition to quantitative genetics, linking it more directly to molecular genetics.

## Historical Context

The founder of quantitative genetics - Sir Ronald Fisher - perceived much of this when he proposed the first mathematics of this branch of genetics.(no content)Originally developed in 1918 by Ronald Fisher, it is based on the idea that variation in a quantitative trait is influenced by an infinitely large number of genes, each of which makes an infinitely small (infinitesimal) contribution to the phenotype, as well as by environmental factors.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Quantitative genetics is the study of quantitative traits, which are phenotypes that vary continuously—such as height or mass—as opposed to phenotypes and gene-products that are discretely identifiable—such as eye-colour, or the presence of a particular biochemical.

## Key Concepts

Polygenic inheritance refers to inheritance of a phenotypic characteristic (trait) that is attributable to two or more genes and can be measured quantitatively, while multifactorial inheritance refers to polygenic inheritance that also includes interactions with the environment.(no content)Multifactorial traits outside of illness result in what we see as continuous characteristics in organisms, especially human organisms such as: height, skin color, and body mass.

## Quantitative Trait Loci (QTLs)

A quantitative trait locus (QTL) is a locus (section of DNA) that correlates with variation of a quantitative trait in the phenotype of a population of organisms.(no content)Analysis of quantitative trait loci, or QTLs, is a more recent addition to quantitative genetics, linking it more directly to molecular genetics.

## Historical Context

The founder of quantitative genetics - Sir Ronald Fisher - perceived much of this when he proposed the first mathematics of this branch of genetics.(no content)Originally developed in 1918 by Ronald Fisher, it is based on the idea that variation in a quantitative trait is influenced by an infinitely large number of genes, each of which makes an infinitely small (infinitesimal) contribution to the phenotype, as well as by environmental factors.

Web search results for query: "microbiome"

Links: [{"title":"Microbiome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiome"},{"title":"Human microbiome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_microbiome"},{"title":"Gut microbiota - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gut_microbiota"},{"title":"Microbiota - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiota"},{"title":"Marine microbiome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_microbiome"},{"title":"Brain microbiome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brain_microbiome"},{"title":"Microbiome in the Drosophila gut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiome_in_the_Drosophila_gut"},{"title":"List of human microbiota - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_human_microbiota"},{"title":"Plant microbiome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_microbiome"},{"title":"Microbiome-wide association study - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiome-wide_association_study"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of the microbiome based on the search results:

## Definition

A microbiome is the community of microorganisms that can usually be found living together in any given habitat. More formally, it is defined as "a characteristic microbial community occupying a reasonably well-defined habitat which has distinct physio-chemical properties. The term thus not only refers to the microorganisms involved but also encompasses their theatre of activity".

## Components

Most microbiome researchers agree bacteria, archaea, fungi, algae, and small protists should be considered as members of the microbiome.(no content)The microbiota consists of all living members forming the microbiome.

## Human Microbiome

The human microbiome is the aggregate of all microbiota that reside on or within human tissues and biofluids along with the corresponding anatomical sites in which they reside, including the gastrointestinal tract, skin, mammary glands, seminal fluid, uterus, ovarian follicles, lung, saliva, oral mucosa, ocular surface, and the biliary tract.(no content)The number of bacterial cells in the human body is estimated to be around 38 trillion, while the estimate for human cells is around 30 trillion.

## The Gut Microbiome

The gut is the main location of the human microbiome.(no content)The gut microbiota has broad impacts, including effects on colonization, resistance to pathogens, maintaining the intestinal epithelium, metabolizing dietary and pharmaceutical compounds, controlling immune function, and even behavior through the gut–brain axis.

## Importance Across Organisms

All animals and plants form associations with microorganisms, including protists, bacteria, archaea, fungi, and viruses. Microbiomes play crucial roles in the health and function of diverse organisms ranging from plants to marine animals to humans.

Web search results for query: "phenotype"

Links: [{"title":"Phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype"},{"title":"The Extended Phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Extended_Phenotype"},{"title":"Phenotype (album) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(album)"},{"title":"Phenotype (igneous petrology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(igneous_petrology)"},{"title":"Human Phenotype Ontology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Phenotype_Ontology"},{"title":"Phenotype microarray - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_microarray"},{"title":"Phenotype mixing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_mixing"},{"title":"Phenotype (clinical medicine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(clinical_medicine)"},{"title":"Genotype–phenotype distinction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype–phenotype_distinction"},{"title":"Senescence-associated secretory phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Senescence-associated_secretory_phenotype"}]

Here are the search results for "phenotype":

## Definition

In genetics, the phenotype is the set of observable characteristics or traits of an organism.(no content)The term covers all traits of an organism other than its genome, including the organism's morphology (physical form and structure), its developmental processes, its biochemical and physiological properties, and all its behavior.

## How Phenotype Forms

An organism's phenotype results from two basic factors: the expression of an organism's unique profile of genes (its genotype) and the influence of environmental factors experienced by that same organism which influence the variable expression of said genes.

## Genotype vs. Phenotype

The "genotype" is an organism's full hereditary information, while the "phenotype" is an organism's actual observed properties, such as morphology, development, or behavior.(no content)Wilhelm Johannsen proposed the genotype–phenotype distinction in 1911 to make clear the difference between an organism's hereditary material and 'all the typical phenomena of the organic world'.

## Behavioral Phenotypes

Behaviors and their consequences are also phenotypes, since behaviors are observable characteristics, and behavioral phenotypes include cognitive, personality, and behavioral patterns.

## Examples and Applications

The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) is a formal ontology of human phenotypes developed as part of the Monarch Initiative, and currently contains over 13,000 terms and over 156,000 annotations to hereditary diseases.

Links: [{"title":"Heritability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritability"},{"title":"Heritability of IQ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritability_of_IQ"},{"title":"Missing heritability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missing_heritability_problem"},{"title":"Talk:Heritability of IQ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Heritability_of_IQ"},{"title":"Heritability of autism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritability_of_autism"},{"title":"Heritable jurisdictions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritable_jurisdictions"},{"title":"Heritable Jurisdictions (Scotland) Act 1746 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritable_Jurisdictions_(Scotland)_Act_1746"},{"title":"Genetic disorder - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_disorder"},{"title":"DNA mismatch repair - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNA_mismatch_repair"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about heritability:

## Definition

Heritability is a statistic used in the fields of breeding and genetics that estimates the degree of variation in a phenotypic trait in a population that is due to genetic variation between individuals in that population.(no content)The concept can be expressed as: "What is the proportion of the variation in a given trait within a population that is not explained by the environment or random chance?"

## Key Characteristics

Heritability estimates take values ranging from 0 to 1; a heritability estimate of 1 indicates that all variation in the trait is genetic and a heritability estimate of 0 indicates that none of the variation is genetic.

## Common Misunderstandings

One critical point of confusion is that heritability measures the fraction of phenotype variability that can be attributed to genetic variation, but this is not the same as saying that this fraction of an individual phenotype is caused by genetics.(no content)Heritability measures the proportion of variation in a trait that can be attributed to genes, not the proportion of a trait caused by genes; thus, if the environment relevant to a given trait changes in a way that affects all members of the population equally, the mean value of the trait will change without any change in its heritability.

## Important Considerations

Heritability can change without any genetic change occurring, such as when the environment starts contributing to more variation. Additionally, heritability is specific to a particular population in a particular environment.

Links: [{"title":"Heritability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritability"},{"title":"Heritability of IQ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritability_of_IQ"},{"title":"Missing heritability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missing_heritability_problem"},{"title":"Talk:Heritability of IQ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Heritability_of_IQ"},{"title":"Heritability of autism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritability_of_autism"},{"title":"Heritable jurisdictions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritable_jurisdictions"},{"title":"Heritable Jurisdictions (Scotland) Act 1746 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritable_Jurisdictions_(Scotland)_Act_1746"},{"title":"Genetic disorder - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_disorder"},{"title":"DNA mismatch repair - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNA_mismatch_repair"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about heritability:

## Definition

Heritability is a statistic used in the fields of breeding and genetics that estimates the degree of variation in a phenotypic trait in a population that is due to genetic variation between individuals in that population.(no content)The concept can be expressed as: "What is the proportion of the variation in a given trait within a population that is not explained by the environment or random chance?"

## Key Characteristics

Heritability estimates take values ranging from 0 to 1; a heritability estimate of 1 indicates that all variation in the trait is genetic and a heritability estimate of 0 indicates that none of the variation is genetic.

## Common Misunderstandings

One critical point of confusion is that heritability measures the fraction of phenotype variability that can be attributed to genetic variation, but this is not the same as saying that this fraction of an individual phenotype is caused by genetics.(no content)Heritability measures the proportion of variation in a trait that can be attributed to genes, not the proportion of a trait caused by genes; thus, if the environment relevant to a given trait changes in a way that affects all members of the population equally, the mean value of the trait will change without any change in its heritability.

## Important Considerations

Heritability can change without any genetic change occurring, such as when the environment starts contributing to more variation. Additionally, heritability is specific to a particular population in a particular environment.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about host-pathogen interactions:

## Definition

The host-pathogen interaction is defined as how microbes or viruses sustain themselves within host organisms on a molecular, cellular, organismal or population level.

## Types of Interactions

There are three main types of host-pathogen interactions based on their nature:

1. **Commensalism**: The pathogen benefits while the host gains nothing from the interaction.(no content)An example is Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron, which resides in the human intestinal tract but provides no known benefits.

2. **Mutualism**: Both the pathogen and the host benefit from the interaction, as seen in the human stomach where many bacteria aid in breaking down nutrients for the host, and in return, our bodies act as their ecosystem.

3. **Parasitism**: The pathogen benefits from the relationship while the host is harmed, such as the unicellular Plasmodium falciparum parasite which causes malaria in humans.

## Transmission Methods

Organisms can be classified as pathogens based on their mode of transmission, including food-borne, airborne, waterborne, blood-borne, and vector-borne.

## Disease Mechanisms

Within the host, pathogens can cause disease and trigger the immune response; microbes and fungi cause symptoms due to their high rate of reproduction and tissue invasion, resulting in an immune response as phagocytes break down the bacteria within the host.

Web search results for query: "symbiosis"

Links: [{"title":"Symbiosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbiosis"},{"title":"Developmental symbiosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Developmental_symbiosis"},{"title":"Symbiogenesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbiogenesis"},{"title":"Emotional symbiosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotional_symbiosis"},{"title":"Commensalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commensalism"},{"title":"Ectosymbiosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ectosymbiosis"},{"title":"Symbiosis (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbiosis_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Symbiosis (chemical) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbiosis_(chemical)"},{"title":"Symbiotic bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbiotic_bacteria"},{"title":"Marine microbial symbiosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_microbial_symbiosis"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about symbiosis:

## Definition
Symbiosis is any close and long-term biological interaction between two organisms of different species.(no content)In 1879, Heinrich Anton de Bary defined symbiosis as "the living together of unlike organisms".

## Types of Symbiotic Relationships
Symbiosis can be classified in several ways:

- **Mutualism**: The term is sometimes more exclusively used in a restricted, mutualistic sense, where both symbionts contribute to each other's subsistence, meaning that they benefit each other in some way.

- **Commensalism**: Commensalism is a long-term biological interaction (symbiosis) in which members of one species gain benefits while those of the other species neither benefit nor are harmed.

- **Parasitism**: In a parasitic relationship, the parasite benefits while the host is harmed.

## Forms of Symbiosis
It can be obligate, meaning that one or both of the organisms depend on each other for survival, or facultative, meaning that they can subsist independently. Additionally, when one organism lives on the surface of another, such as head lice on humans, it is called ectosymbiosis; when one partner lives inside the tissues of another, such as Symbiodinium within coral, it is termed endosymbiosis.

## Evolutionary Significance
Symbiosis has often driven the evolution of species; mutualism has enabled species for example to colonise new environments.

### Paper Classification
